Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Effects of Noise on Aquatic Life (2013)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI requests funding for The Third International Conference on the Effects of Noise on Aquatic Life will take place in Budapest, Hungary, August 11-16, 2013. This meeting follows two successful meetings in Nyborg (2007) and Cork (2010), both of which NSF provided partial support. The major goal of the conference will be to define the current state of knowledge on the impact of underwater noise and, in particular, explore the progress made in this field in the three years since the second Conference. The third Conference will place strong emphasis on recent research results, the sharing of ideas, discussion of experimental approaches, and analysis of regulatory issues.

Broader Impacts

The meeting should help shape future research and understanding of effects of noise on aquatic life. Based on experience from the earlier meetings, the interactions and networking that took place has resulted in new collaborations between investigators, a broader understanding of the science that can be used in their work by regulators, a better understanding of regulatory issues by scientists and industry, and substantial cross-fertilization of experimental design and approaches by investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This conference addressed the very important issue of effects of man-made noise on aquatic life. This is an issue of braod international importance since there is an increase in man-made marine activities that produce loud sounds, such as development of wind farms and oil and gas exploration off shore. In addition, the increased shipping in many areas increases the noise levels. Both impulsive and continuous sounds were addressed, and presentations (over 150) included most sound sources as well as studies involving marine mammals, fishes, turtles, and invertebrates.

THe conference brought together scientists, regulators, industry, and enviromental groups to share new data and to discuss the latest ideas about potential effects of sounds and potential mitigation methods.  The meeting fostered a great deal of netowrking and interactions that could not happen at regular scientific meetings which focus on only one animal group or sound source. This meeting, instead, covered broad issues and encouraged extensive interactions.

Participants came from over 20 countries from all continents but Africa (and we reached out to several African colleagues), and included not only senior scholars and others, but there were a large number of graduate students and postdocs.

The outcome of the meeting will be a major book to be published by Springer that will have the papers from the meeting. This volume will contain perhaps 150 scholarly papers.
